TopicTitle: Twitch Thursdays: The Best Minmus Takeoff You'll Ever See

Articles.Content:
<p><img src="https://31.media.tumblr.com/e6b9796e0425d604ccf4dd4df2733721/tumblr_inline_n7suwuhuAC1rr2wit.jpg"/></p>

<p><object data="http://www.twitch.tv/widgets/archive_embed_player.swf" height="378" id="clip_embed_player_flash" type="application/x-shockwave-flash" width="420"><param name="movie" value="http://www.twitch.tv/widgets/archive_embed_player.swf"><param name="allowScriptAccess" value="always"><param name="allowNetworking" value="all"><param name="allowFullScreen" value="true"><param name="flashvars" value="title=The%2Bbest%2BMinmus%2Btakeoff%2Byou%2527ll%2Bever%2Bsee&channel=frankbashone&auto_play=false&start_volume=25&chapter_id=4509542"></object></p>

<p><a href="http://www.twitch.tv/frankbashone/profile"><strong><span class="channelname">Frankbashone</span></strong></a> called this clip <em>The Best Minmus Takeoff You’ll Ever See.</em> We’ll let you be the judge of that. Was it, in fact, the best you’ve ever seen?</p>
Shway! So uh. How'd you possibly get into that position?
I liked what I saw, but how'd he get into that situation? Did he deliberately put the ship on a crash trajectory, EVA the kerbal and fly down, then jetpack back up to rendezvous before crashing?
I don't get it, what's so spectacular? EVA'ing over to a ship?

I don't get it, what's so spectacular? EVA'ing over to a ship?

A falling ship.

A falling ship.

Gravity on Minmus is pretty low, so you usually have plenty of time.
The really spectacular thing was that - by pure chance - his slightly panicked escape trajectory took him almost directly home without any faffing around with nodes and multiple burns.

I'm with Blizzy. I appreciate the idea (I never thought of it) and the showmanship, but the fact that he went WAY over the ship and had to come back down, and STILL had time to hit the engines shows how easy this was. In map mode, you can see your time to collision by trying to make a maneuver node at the point of impact, and it would be trivial to boost upward a bit more to make it any reasonable number of minutes before the ship would crash.

Actually the hardest part was probably getting the Kerbal down to the surface quickly without lithobraking him to death, and they didn't even show that part

I'm with Blizzy. I appreciate the idea (I never thought of it) and the showmanship, but the fact that he went WAY over the ship and had to come back down, and STILL had time to hit the engines shows how easy this was. In map mode, you can see your time to collision by trying to make a maneuver node at the point of impact, and it would be trivial to boost upward a bit more to make it any reasonable number of minutes before the ship would crash.

Actually the hardest part was probably getting the Kerbal down to the surface quickly without lithobraking him to death, and they didn't even show that part

^

I'm with him, not that hard at all, The "Best" maybe not still since doing anything on Minmus is down right easy with nearly no gravity, maybe the most interesting take off? sure.

Actually the hardest part was probably getting the Kerbal down to the surface quickly without lithobraking him to death

Kerbals can do Kerbin reentry and landing without a ship, so landing a Kerbal on Minmus probably is not very hard.

Actually the hardest part was probably getting the Kerbal down to the surface quickly without lithobraking him to death, and they didn't even show that part

Or perhaps he already had the Kerbal stationed at the lithosphere and was landing the ship via remote guidance.

Kerbals can do Kerbin reentry and landing without a ship, so landing a Kerbal on Minmus probably is not very hard.

I said it was the hardest part, not that it was particularly hard.
